case_data.name: Manning v. Rogers
case_data.summary:
NOTE: This case is being tracked in close to real time by the Stanford/MIT Healthy Elections Project. So for information, see their tracker.

According to their summary as of 09/05/2020,

Facts/claims: Secretary of State has delayed signature counting and verification for a State Question (law prohibiting extreme sentencing) due to COVID-19 related difficulties. Court agreed and directed Secretary of State to begin signature count to consider petition.

Petitioners/Proponents of Initiative Petition 421, State Question 805, Theodis  ___ 
and  Gene  Rainbolt,  respectfully  request  that  the  Court,  pursuant  to  Article  7,  § 4  of the 
Oklahoma Constitution,  assume original jurisdiction and  issue  a writ of mandamus or other 
appropriate  extraordinary  relief directing  Respondent,  Michael  Rogers,  in  his  capacity  as 
Oklahoma Secretary of State, to accept Proponents'  initiative petition~signed by more than 
260,000 Oklahomans~for filing, and timely commence (and complete) the signature-counting 
process. 
In support of this Application and Petition, Petitioners show the Court: 
L  Petitioner Theodis Manning is a resident and citizen of the State of Oklahoma, 
and is one of the named Proponents of Initiative Petition 421, State Question 805. 
2.  Petitioner Gene Rainbolt is a resident and citizen ofthe State of Oklahoma, and is 
one of the named Proponents of Initiative Petition 421, State Question 805. 
3_  Respondent Michael Rogers is the Oklahoma Secretary of State, and is named in 
his  official  capacity.  Respondent  has  the  authority,  and  obligation,  to  accept 
Petitioner/Proponents'  initiative  petition  for  filing  and  begin  (and  complete)  the  counting 
process. See 34 O.S. § 8.  RECEIVED 

4.  As explained in the accompanying brief, there is no mechanism for appeal of the 
Secretary's refusal to accept Proponents' initiative petition for filing; thus, there is no adequate 
remedy at law. Furthermore, time is of the essence: according to the State Election Board, all 
measures must be finalized by August 19, 2020 in order to be printed on the November general 
election ballot. Given the number of steps that remain to be completed in the initiative process, 
and the  potential for  delay under current circumstances,  an  original  action  in  this  Court is 
Proponents' only available and adequate remedy. 
5.  This application is not filed within ten days of any scheduled trial or hearing date. 
WHEREFORE, Petitioners pray that this Court assume original jurisdiction of this matter 
and issue a writ of mandamus or other appropriate extraordinary relief. 
Respectfully Submitted,

ORDER 
~1  Original jurisdiction is assumed. Fent v. Contingency Review Bd., 2007 OK 27, 
~11, 163 P.3d 512 (the Court may assume jurisdiction in a publici juris controversy 
where there is an urgency and need for a judicial determination).  The extraordinary 
relief sought by Proponents of Initiative Petition 421, State Question 805  is granted. 
~2  Okla. Con st. Art. 5, § 2 provides that the first power reserved by the people is 
the initiative.  Respondent's integral role and non-discretionary duties with respect 
to the initiative process are plainly set forth in the Constitution.  Under Okla. Canst. 
Art.  5,  § 3, initiative petitions "shall be filed with the Secretary of State." See also 
Okla. Canst. Art. 5, § 4. When initiative petitions submitting a proposed measure to 
the people for their ratification or rejection are offered to the Secretary of State for 
filing, "it is his duty to file same." Threadgill v.  Cross, 1910 OK 165, ~5, 109 P. 558, 

distinguished on other grounds by In re Initiative Petition No.  349, State Question 
No. 642, 1992 OK 122, 838 P.2d 1 (noting there is no controversy about the nature 
of this duty and there can be none). 
~3  Pursuant to  34  O.S.  Supp.  2015,  §  8(G),  proponents of a referendum  or 
initiative petition may terminate the circulation period any time during said period by 
certifying to the Secretary of State (1) the petitions have been filed with the Secretary 
of State, (2) no petitions are in circulation, and (3) proponents will not circulate any 
more petitions. Proponents have tendered for filing the signed petitions in the instant 
cause.  Therefore, pursuant to the text of the statute, Respondent "shall begin the 
counting process." /d. 
~4  While the signature-gathering deadline was temporarily halted, or tolled, by 
Respondent on March 18, 2020, with the approval of the Governor under the latter's 
emergency powers pursuant to the statewide CO VI D-19 emergency, this does not 
alter Proponent's statutory rights under 34 O.S. Supp. 2015, § 8(G). The circulation 
period began, but it has not ended, and thus we are still within the circulation period. 
In re Initiative Petition No. 397, State Question No.  767, 2014 OK 23, ~9, 326 P.3d 
496 (goal of statutory construction is to ascertain legislative intent from a plain and 
ordinary reading of the statute). 
~5  The Court notes Respondent has expressed concerns that commencing the 
signature-counting  process  amid  the  COVID-19  Pandemic and  current  state  of 
emergency will present practical difficulties.  There is also the foremost desire and 
2 

duty to protect the safety and welfare of all of those involved in the process. In this 
regard, beginning in mid-March, the Governor issued Executive Orders authorizing 
state agencies to make necessary emergency acquisitions to fulfill the purpose of 
the emergency declaration,  and  requiring  the  promulgation  of emergency rules 
necessary to respond to the emergency. 
~6  Based  on  the  materials  provided,  the  Court  finds  Respondent  has  not 
established  the  signature-counting  process cannot be  performed  in  an  efficient 
manner, while also taking the necessary safety precautions for those involved.  The 
Court is not convinced Respondent would be unable to procure the tools to carry out 
the signature-counting  process.  To  this  end,  the  Court notes  Proponents  have 
offered to secure a suitable facility (where social distancing guidelines are more 
capable of being observed) at their own expense. The duties imposed upon the 
Secretary of State regarding  the  initiative and  referendum  is  ministerial,  and  is 
mandatory. Norris v.  Cross, 1909 OK 316, syll., 105 P.  1000. 
~7  Accordingly, a Writ of Mandamus is hereby issued directing the Respondent 
to accept for filing the signed petitions for Initiative Petition 421, State Question 805, 
within ten (1 0) calendar days of this Order, and to thereafter begin and complete the 
signature-counting process expeditiously. 
~8  DONE  BY ORDER OF  THE SUPREME COURT  IN  CONFERENCE THIS 
/12. 
~ ~ 
26THDAYOFMAY,2020. 
CHIEF JUSTICE 
Gurich, C.J., Darby, V.C.J., Kauger, Edmondson, Combs, JJ., concur; 
Kane and Rowe, JJ., dissent; 
Winchester, J., not voting; 
Colbert, J., not participating.

Because critical deadlines for the next general election ballot are rapidly approaching, 
I 
and because of the need to respect the "importance of timeliness" in election-related issues, 1 
Petitioners/Proponents of Initiative Petition 421, State Question 805, Theodis Manning and 
I 
Gene Rainbolt, have made clear that they wish to forego the remainder of their signature-
I 
circulation period and submit their petitions to the Secretary-allowing signature-counting, 
and  the remaining steps  in  the initiative process, to  be  completed timely.  Citing a prior 
I 
decision tolling the  signature-circulation period,  however, Respondent,  Secretary of State 
I 
Michael  Rogers, has flatly  refused to  accept Proponents' previously signed petitions for 
filing. 
I 
The Secretary's refusal is contrary to both his duties under the governing statute, 34 
I 
O.S. § 8(G), and the People's fundamental and "sacred" right of initiative. Proponents thus 
respectfully request that the Court assume original jurisdiction and issue a writ of mandamus 
I 
or  other  appropriate  extraordinary  relief,  directing  the  Secretary  to  accept  Proponents' 
I  initiative  petition-signed  by  more  than  260,000  Oklahomans-for  filing  and  timely 
commence (and complete) the signature-counting process. 
I 
BACKGROUND 
I  In early March of this year, the Proponents of SQ805 were on track to turn in a record 
number  of signatures  in  favor  of placing  the  criminal  justice  reform  initiative  on  the 
I 
November 2020 ballot. With more than 10% of their circulation period remaining, more than 
I  260,000  Oklahomans  had  already  signed  the  petition  and  exercised  their "sacred"  and 
"precious" right to "institute change through the initiative process." In re Initiative Petition 
I 
No. 348, 1991 OK 110, 'i[ 5, 820 P.2d 772,775. 
I 
1 Save the Ill. River, Jnv. v. State ex rei Okla. State Election Bd., 2016 OK 86, 'i[ 6, 378 P.3d 
1220, 1224 (Combs, J. concurring). 
I 
I 

I 
I 
As  this  Court  is  aware,  however,  the  SARS-CoV-2  pandemic  has  upended  the 
I 
initiative process.  On March  15, 2020, with  II days remaining in  the  90-day circulation 
period previously set by the Secretary, Oklahoma's Governor declared a state of emergency. 
I 
The next morning, Proponents---.;oncerned about the health and  safety of their signature 
I 
collectors  and  of the  public-temporarily  halted  all  signature  collection  and  filed  an 
emergency motion in this Court, seeking to toll its circulation period. In response, on March 
I 
18, 2020, Secretary Rogers issued a general directive "toll[ing] the 90-day circulation period 
I 
for initiative petitions." App. Tab A. 
At the time Proponents sought to toll their signature collection deadline, there was 
I 
hope that the coronavirus outbreak in Oklahoma could be contained, and that the last II days 
I 
of signature collection could be resumed in a timely manner. Now, however, it is clear this 
will not be the case. Although state agencies and some businesses are beginning to reopen, 
I 
conditions will not soon allow for large-scale  inter-personal circulation of petitions. And 
I 
while the "90-day circulation period for initiative petitions" has been tolled, App. Tab A, the 
various other applicable statutory deadlines-including ballot printing deadlines-have not. 
I 
Nor,  of course,  have  the  practicalities  of making  it  through  the  remaining  steps  of 
I 
Oklahoma's complex initiative petition process before August  19, 2020-the deadline by 
which the Election Board says measures must be finalized for inclusion on the November 
I 
general election ballot? 
I  Later in  March,  then,  SQ805  campaign representatives contacted the Secretary of 
State's office, noting that they may well wish to forego the remainder of their signature-
I 
collection period as  provided  in  34  O.S.  § S(G),  and asking how they  could turn  in the 
I 
2 See https://www.ok.gov/elections/documents/2020%20Statutory%20Election%20Dates%20 
and%20Deadlines.pdf. 
I 
2 
I 

I 
I 
signatures  that  had  already  been  gathered  so  the  counting  process  could  begin.  The 
I 
Secretary's office responded that, "[d]ue to the state of emergency and the toll being placed 
I  on all active petitions on record with our office3, and also since our offices are closed to the 
public, we are unable to accept signature pamphlets for filing." App. Tab B. 
I 
Campaign representatives continued to follow up, requesting further details on when 
the  office  would  reopen  and  how  they  could  turn  in  signatures;  the  Secretary's  office 
I 
continued to  demur.  See,  e.g.,  App.  Tab  C.  On  April  22,  2020, however,  the  Governor 
I 
announced his "Open Up and Recover Safely (OURS) Plan."4 Under that plan, the Governor 
declared that, beginning April 24, 2020, numerous organizations and businesses-including 
I 
retail and even personal care businesses, such as hair and nail salons-could safely open on 
I 
an  appointments-only  basis,  so  long  as  employees  and  customers  follow  certain  social-
distancing guidelines. !d. 
I 
Since  that time,  representatives  of the  SQ805  campmgn  have  attempted to  work 
I 
collaboratively with the Secretary's office. They repeatedly requested information about how 
and when they could tum in previously obtained signatures so that signature counting, and 
I 
the other remaining steps in the initiative petition process, could timely proceed. App. Tab B, 
I  C.  They proposed a number of options to safely deliver sealed boxes of signed petitions 
without any personal contact. 5 Id . And they patiently waited while, for weeks, the Secretary 
I 
3 Notably, the order issued by the Secretary of State "toll[ing] the 90-day circulation period 
I  for  initiative  petitions" addresses only circulation,  and says nothing  about  filing  already 
completed and signed petitions. 
4 https://www.okcommerce.gov/covidl9/ours-plan/. 
I 
5  Sealed boxes of signed initiative petitions have been sitting in a secure storage facility, 
untouched, for more than a month. Campaign representatives have offered to deliver these 
I  boxes, with no more than two individuals (wearing masks and gloves) to carry them, to any 
secure  location the  Secretary would  like.  No campaign representative  would  need to  go 
within six feet of any state employee. 
I 
3 
I 

I 
I 
continued to promise that his office was "working on its reopening plan" and would have 
I 
"more details" for Proponents "soon." App. Tab C. 
On Monday, May 4, the Capitol-where the Secretary's executive/legislative office is 
I 
located-officially reopened to the public  by appointment6  At 4 p.m.  on May 5,  2020, 
I 
however, the Secretary finally made official what Proponents were beginning to suspect: 
even though both the governing statute (34 O.S. § 8) and his tolling letter clearly contemplate 
I 
early termination of the signature-collection period at Proponents' election; and even though 
I 
signature tum-in can be accomplished without any person-to-person contact or risk to staff; 
and even though the Governor had declared it safe to conduct public business, the Secretary 
I 
nevertheless would refuse to accept the signed initiative petitions for filing so long as the 
I 
emergency declaration is in place. App. Tab B. 
Time is running short. Deadlines for the November general election ballot are rapidly 
I 
approaching, and until the Secretary accepts the signed petitions, it will not be possible to 
I 
count the signatures, determine numerical  sufficiency, or commence any post-circulation 
legal process-all ministerial steps integral to the exercise of "[t]he first power reserved by 
I 
the people." In re Initiative Petition 403, State Question No.  779, 2016 OK I,~ 3, 367 P.3d 
I  472,  474.  The  Secretary is  not entitled to  simply  refuse to  accept  an  initiative  petition. 
Proponents thus respectfully request that the Court issue a writ of mandamus compelling 
I 
Secretary  Rogers  to  accept  and  file  their  signed  petitions,  and  timely  commence  (and 
I  complete) the signature-counting process. 
I 
I 
6 https://www.normantranscript.com/news/oklahoma!state-capitol-to-reopen-topublic/article_  
8a33ad78-dbd l-5d8f-9e ll-6160a9c913 83 .html. 
I 
4 
I 

I 
I 
ARGUMENT AND AUTHORITY 
I 
I.  This Court Should Assume Original Jurisdiction 
When the People of Oklahoma and the Oklahoma Legislature empowered this Court 
I 
to assume original jurisdiction and compel performance of ministerial duty, they did so to 
I 
safeguard against circumstances where, as here, a fundamental right is at risk; those persons 
tasked with carrying it out have not performed; and the remedy must come quickly. Okla. 
I 
Const. Art. VII,§ 4; 12 O.S. § 1451; cf Okla. Const. Art. V, § 2 ("first power reserved by the 
I  people is the initiative"). Indeed, mandamus is an appropriate intervention where "there is: 
(I) a clear legal right vested in the petitioner; (2) a refusal to perform a plain legal duty which 
I 
does not involve the exercise of discretion; and (3) [] inadequacy of other relief." Price v. Bd. 
I  ofCty. Comm'rs of Pawnee Cty., 2016 OK 16, ~ 6, 371 P.3d 1089, 1091; State ex rei. Dep't 
of Transp.  v. Post, 2005 OK 69, ~ 2 n.1, 125 P .3d 1183, 1185 n.1; State ex rei. Indep. Sch 
I 
Dis!. No.1 v. Barnes, 1988 OK 70, ~ 18,762 P.2d 921,923. 
I  Because the "people's right to institute change through [] initiative[] is a fundamental 
characteristic of Oklahoma government," In re Initiative Petition No.  360, 1994 OK 97, ~ 9, 
I 
879 P .2d 810, 814, there is no question here of right. Mandamus has thus long been used to 
I  compel performance of ministerial duties associated with the initiative petition process. See 
Norris v.  Cross,  1909 OK 316, 105 P.  1000, 1000 ("The duties of the Secretary of State to 
I 
file referendum petitions when presented to him ... are purely ministerial; and, upon refusal 
I  to perform same, he may be compelled to do so by mandamus."); see also. e.g., App. Tab D 
(article about episode where Court ordered a different Secretary Rogers to open his office to 
I 
accept the filing of a different petition); Black v.  Wood,  1952 OK 276, ~~ 14-15, 249 P.2d 
699,  701  (writ of mandamus  appropriate to  compel  town  clerk to  publish  notice  of an 
I 
initiative petition); Threadgill v.  Cross,  1910 OK 165,  109 P.  558,  559--60, overruled on 
I 
5 
I 

I 
I 
other grounds by,  In  re Initiative  Petition No.  349,  !992 OK  122,  838  P.2d  I  (writ of 
I 
mandamus appropriate to compel Secretary of State to submit initiative petition to a vote of 
the People). 
I 
Original jurisdiction is further appropriate here because this matter inherently affects 
I 
not only public right, but also public interest. See, e.g., State ex rei. Nesbitt v. Ford, 1967 OK 
186, ~ 9, 434 P.2d 934, 937 ("This court is authorized to and may take original jurisdiction 
I 
and  issue  writs  of mandamus  .  . . to  executive  officers  commanding  them  to  perform 
I 
ministerial duties where the question raised is publici juris"). In less than three months, well

I 
II.  The Secretary Must Accept Submission of IP421 
I 
"A  writ  will  issue  when the  action  sought to  be  compelled  is  purely  ministerial 
because the officer or board, when properly requested to do so, has a mandatory duty to act 
I 
that stands imposed by law." Morton v. Adair Cty. Excise Bd., 1989 OK 174, ~ 4, 780 P.2d 
I  707, 709. Here, the Secretary's duty to accept submission of signed initiative petitions is 
ministerial, and not only legally but also constitutionally mandatory. It is therefore subject to 
I 
mandamus. 
I  First, the Oklahoma Constitution unambiguously provides that "[p] etitions ... for the 
initiative and for the referendum shall be filed with the Secretary of State." Okla. Canst. Art. 
I 
V,  § 3 (emphasis added). The relevant executing provision likewise provides that, "[w]hen 
I  the signed copies of a petition are timely filed, the Secretary of State shall file a copy of the 
proponent's ballot title with the Attorney General, and after conducting a count of the filed, 
I 
6 
I 

I 
I 
signed petition, the  Secretary of State shall certify" the number of signatures counted.  34 
I 
O.S. § 8(H) (emphasis added). The statute also makes clear that the proponents of a petition 
"may terminate the circulation period any time during the ninety-day circulation period by 
I 
certifying to the Secretary of State" that they have ceased circulation and all petitions have 
I 
been filed.  34 O.S. § 8(G). "If the Secretary of State receives such a certification from the 
proponents, the Secretary of State shall begin the counting process." !d. (emphasis addedd). 
I 
The People and  Legislature's use  of the world "shall" in regard to the Secretary's 
I 
duties  indicates that he  lacks discretion as to  whether or not to  accept and  count signed 
petitions. Cf, e.g., Velasco v.  Ruiz, 2019 OK 46, '1]9, 457 P.3d 1014, 1017-18; Okla.  Pub. 
I 
Employees Ass 'n v.  State ex rei.  Okla.  Office of Pers.  Mgmt., 2011  OK 68, '11'11  13-14, n.18, 
I 
267 P.3d 838, 845; N. Coltrane Cmty. Ass'n. Inc. v. Bd. o.fCty. Comm'rs of Okla. City, 2019 
OK CIV APP 72, '1]'1]31-33, 453 P.3d 913,922. If the Secretary refuses to perform his "plain 
I 
legal duty," a writ of mandamus is both necessary and appropriate. Ibid.; Price, 2016 OK 16, 
I 
at '1]6. 
Second, the passive declaration that signed initiative petitions "shall be submitted" to 
I 
the Secretary, Okla. Const. Art. V, § 3, reinforces that the duty to accept signed petitions is a 
I  ministerial act. E.g., Russell v. Harrison, 1912 OK 443, 124 P. 762,763 (Secretary of State's 
initiative petition duties are generally without discretion). Here again, the "ministerial 'shall' 
I 
differs from the discretionary 'may' where the law describes the duty to be performed such 
I  that ... no exercise of discretion necessary." N.  Coltrane, 2019 OK CIV APP 72, at 'I] 31. 
There are not varying degrees to which the Secretary can fulfill the duty at issue: he either 
I 
accepts submission of signed petitions, or he does not. This binary execution of a mandatory 
,I  duty is akin to issuance of a permit. Just as "[w]hen an applicant has complied with all [] 
I

I 
provisions of the statue, issuance of [a] permit is a purely ministerial act," Bozarth, McCord 
I 
& McCrary v.  Okla. Dep't ofTransp., 1991 OK CIV APP 30, 812 P.2d 815, 816, so "when 
the signed copies" of a petition are ready, they may be "timely filed" with the Secretary of 
I 
State who "shall" count them. 34 O.S. § 8 (H). 
I 
Third, a "writ of mandamus" is generally appropriate to compel the Secretary "to act 
upon [an] initiative petition and determine the sufficiency thereof." In re Initiative Petition 
I 
No.  2 of Cushing, 1932 OK 124, 10 P.2d 271, 274. Accepting signed petitions is not only 
I 
integral to acting upon a petition, but also a clear statutory predicate for "conducting a count 
of the filed, signed petition" to determine sufficiency. 34 O.S. § S(H). And, given that the 
I 
Secretary has both a statutory and constitutional "fixed duty" to accept submission of signed 
I 
petitions,  it  is  particularly appropriate  for this  Court to  take  "action to  require  [him]  to 
perform that duty." In re Initiative Petition No.  260, State Question No.  377, 1956 OK 196, 
I 
298 P.2d 753, 756; see also Blackv. Wood, 1952 OK 276, at'\['\[ 14-15. 
I 
Last, mandating acceptance of signed initiative petitions to preserve timely exercise 
of right accords not only with this Court's role in requiring an official "to perform an official 
I 
act," Price, 2016 OK 16, at'\[ 6, but also this Court's efforts to guard the People's right to 
I  initiative. E.g.,  Okla.  Oil & Gas Ass'n v.  Thompson, 2018 OK 26, '\[ 4, 424 P.3d 345, 347. It 
is unclear when and if life will return to normal.7 It is likewise unclear just how long it will 
I 
take to count signatures and process any subsequent protests. But the fact that more than 
I  260,000  Oklahomans  have  already  asked  for  a  vote  on  SQ805--<Iespite  the  shortened 
circulation period-shows that Proponents must be allowed to further the initiative process in
